pr_title: Update docs links and add SSL debug info

timeline.message: Update docs links and add SSL debug info

timeline.bodyText: [very minor] maybe split error message in two parts, with "set logging level to info" only if it's not already enabled. Otherwise that error message is confusing.
timeline.author: SylvainJuge

timeline.bodyText: why not log e1 (or at least it's error message), something like log.error("unable to get cipher suite {}", e) ?
timeline.author: SylvainJuge

replies.bodyText: Because it is not interesting for our purpose, it's just a premature check on a non-initialized connection done for info logging. I am falling back to doing what I need to do on non-initialized connections.
replies.author: eyalkoren

timeline.bodyText: [question] could this allows to easily spot a missing certificate (or CA) in trust store ?
timeline.author: SylvainJuge

replies.bodyText: Good question! I spent quite some time looking for a way to get the effective truststore and keystore used to create the connection, but it's only available on the internal implementations, not exposed for external query (at least I couldn't find a way). We can instrument to find that, but.... Maybe in the next enhancement 🙂
replies.author: eyalkoren

timeline.bodyText: [wording] While it is recommended to keep this default behavior, you can change it through the <<config-verify-server-cert>> configuration.

timeline.bodyText:
[wording] split in two distinct cases for clarity (I know users tend to get this wrong)

If APM Server uses a self-signed certificate, you have to add the self-signed certificate to JVM truststore
If APM Server uses a certificate signed by a custom (or unknown) Certificate Authority (CA), you have to add the CA certificate to JVM truststore.

 [float]

-By default, when using HTTPS to communicate with APM Server, the agents will verify the identity

+By default, when using HTTPS to communicate with APM Server, the agents will verify the identity of the APM Server by authenticating its certificate.
+It is not recommended to change this default, however it is possible through the <<config-verify-server-cert>> configuration.
 
-If the certificate used by the APM Server is self-signed, you would need to add the same certificate
-(or the root certificate of the custom CA that signed it)
-to the JVM's truststore. You can find which truststore is used by setting `-Djavax.net.debug=all`
-in the command line. Typically, it would be `$JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/security/cacerts`.
+If the certificate used by the APM Server is self-signed, you would need to add the same certificate (or the root certificate of the custom CA that signed it) to the JVM's truststore.

replies.bodyText: It's one case actually - a self-signed is still signed by a private (could be ad-hoc) CA. So you can either add the leaf certificate or the CA root certificate
replies.author: eyalkoren

timeline.bodyText: [wording] JVM truststore is usually stored in $JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/security/cacerts file.
